book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 344 - (Hasan) 'If usury (Riba) and adultery (Zina) appear openly in a town, they have brought upon themselves the punishment of Allah.' Hasan. Narrated by Al-Hakim.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 345 - (Hasan) 'The sanctity of a person's wealth is like the sanctity of his blood.' Hasan due to the sum of its paths. Narrated by Abu Nu'aym in Al-Hilyah.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 346 - (Sahih) 'Allah has cursed the consumer of usury, its payer, its two witnesses, and its scribe.' Authentic. Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 347 - (Da'if) 'The Prophet ﷺ used to seek refuge from debt and say: 'O Allah, I seek refuge in You from being overcome by debt and the oppression of men.'' Abu Dawood. Weak. It is not found with this wording in Abu Dawood or others as his ﷺ own supplication seeking refuge; rather, it is from his ﷺ teaching to another, and it is not established. Abu Dawood narrated it via Ghassan bin Awf from Al-Jariri from Abu Nadrah from Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ entered the mosque one day and saw a man from the Ansar called Abu Umamah. He said: 'O Abu Umamah, why do I see you sitting in the mosque at a time other than prayer?' He said: 'Worries have adhered to me and debts, O Messenger of Allah.' He said: 'Shall I not teach you words which, if you say them, Allah will remove your worry and pay off your debt?' He said: 'Yes, O Messenger of Allah.' He said: 'Say in the morning and evening: O Allah, I seek refuge in You from anxiety and sorrow, and I seek refuge in You from incapacity and laziness, and I seek refuge in You from cowardice and miserliness, and I seek refuge in You from the burden of debt and being overpowered by men.' This chain is weak. Ghassan bin Awf: Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in Al-Taqrib: 'Lenient in Hadith.' What is authentic from the Prophet ﷺ regarding his seeking refuge is what Al-Bukhari and others narrated from Anas who said: 'I used to hear him ﷺ frequently say: O Allah, I seek refuge in You from anxiety and sorrow, incapacity and laziness, miserliness and cowardice, the burden of debt, and being overpowered by men.'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 348 - (Da'if) '[He said]: 'I seek refuge in Allah from disbelief (Kufr) and debt.' A man said: 'Do you equate disbelief with debt, O Messenger of Allah?' He said: 'Yes.'' Weak. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i, Al-Hakim, and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 349 - (Sahih) He ﷺ used to say frequently in his prayer: 'O Allah, I seek refuge in You from sin and debt.' It was said to him: 'You seek refuge from debt very often, O Messenger of Allah.' He said: 'Verily, when a man falls into debt, he speaks and lies, and promises and breaks his promise.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad from the Hadith of Aisha (RA) that the Prophet ﷺ used to supplicate in his prayer: 'O Allah, I seek refuge in You from the punishment of the grave, and I seek refuge in You from the trial of the False Messiah, and I seek refuge in You from the trials of life and death. O Allah, I seek refuge in You from sin and debt.' She said: Someone said to him, 'How often you seek refuge from debt!' He said... [then he mentioned the text].

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 350 - (Sahih) He ﷺ used not to pray over the deceased if he knew he died with debts and left nothing to pay them off... until Allah granted him conquests and spoils, then he would pay them off himself. Authentic. The author mentioned it by meaning. It is from the Hadith of Jabir and Abu Hurairah, both extracted in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 351 - (Sahih) 'Everything is forgiven for the martyr except debt.' Authentic. Narrated by Muslim from Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 352 - (Sahih) 'Whoever takes people's money intending to pay it back, Allah will pay it back for him; and whoever takes it intending to ruin it, Allah will ruin him.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 353 - (Sahih) That the Prophet ﷺ bought food from a Jew for his family's provision on credit, and he mortgaged an iron coat of mail to him. Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and others. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 354 - (Sahih) 'Whoever pays in advance (for a Salam sale), let him pay in advance for a known measure and a known weight, for a known term.' Authentic. Narrated by the Group from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Abbas. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 355 - (Sahih) The Prophet ﷺ forbade sharecropping (Muzara'ah) on land. Authentic. Narrated by Muslim and Ahmad. See the explanation in the book; its summary is the permissibility of renting land.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 356 - (Da'if) 'The Hand of Allah is over the two partners as long as one of them does not betray the other; but if one of them betrays the other, He removes it from them.' Weak. Narrated by Al-Daraqutni. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 357 - (Da'if) The Messenger ﷺ narrates from his Lord that He says: 'I am the third of the two partners as long as one of them does not betray the other. If one of them betrays the other, I depart from between them.' Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim. Razin added in his Jami': 'and Satan comes.' Weak. As for Razin's addition, we found no basis for it, and Razin is known for odd additions and narrations.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 358 - (Sahih) 'I am closer to every Muslim than his own self. Whoever leaves behind wealth, it is for his heirs; and whoever leaves behind a debt or dependents (Diya' - i.e., young children), then it is for me and upon me.' Authentic. Agreed upon. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 359 - (Sahih) The Prophet ﷺ forbade the wasting of wealth.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 360 - (Sahih) 'Whoever has land, let him cultivate it or grant it to his brother.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ibn Majah from him. He added: 'If he refuses, then let him keep his land.'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 361 - (Sahih) From Jabir who said: 'We used to practice sharecropping (Mukhabarah) during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, obtaining a share from the side [of the field] and from such and such. The Prophet ﷺ said: 'Whoever has land, let him cultivate it or let his brother cultivate it; otherwise, let him abandon it.'' Authentic. Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim. In a narration by Muslim from Abu Al-Zubayr, he said: I heard Jabir bin Abdullah saying: We used to rent land for one-third or one-fourth [of the yield] along the waterways during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ stood up regarding that and said... [then he mentioned the text]. In another narration via Ata' from him, he said: 'Some men from the Companions of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ had surplus lands. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Whoever has surplus land, let him cultivate it or grant it to his brother; if he refuses, let him keep his land.'' In another narration: 'If he cannot cultivate it and is unable to do so, let him grant it to his Muslim brother, and let him not rent it to him.'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 362 - (Sahih) 'For one of you to grant his brother his land is better for him than taking a known rent for it.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, as well as Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Ahmad, and Al-Tabarani.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 363 - (Sahih) In the two Sahihs: That the Messenger of Allah ﷺ employed the people of Khaybar for half of what comes out of it of crops or fruit. Authentic from the Hadith of Ibn Umar. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 364 - (Sahih) Al-Bukhari narrated from Nafi' [reporting from Rafi'] bin Khadij who said: 'We were the people with the most agricultural land - i.e., in Medina. We used to rent out land for a specific portion of it designated for the owner of the land. Sometimes that portion would be ruined while the rest of the land was safe, and sometimes the land would be ruined while that portion was safe. So we were forbidden...' Authentic. The completion of the Hadith is: 'As for gold and silver, they were not used [for rent] at that time.' In a narration: I said to Rafi': 'What about renting it for dinars and dirhams?' Rafi' said: 'There is no harm in [renting] for dinars and dirhams.' All this is in Al-Bukhari and in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 365 - (Sahih) From Rafi' bin Khadij who said: The Prophet ﷺ said: 'What do you do with your fields?' They said: 'We rent them out for a quarter [of the yield] and for measures of dates and barley.' He said: 'Do not do that.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 366 - (Da'if) Zaid bin Thabit narrated that two men disputed regarding land before the Prophet ﷺ. He said: 'If this is your situation, then do not rent out the farms.' Weak. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Majah.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 367 - (Sahih) From Ibn Abbas: 'The Prophet ﷺ did not forbid sharecropping, but he commanded that they be gentle with one another.' Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and Al-Tabarani. Al-Tirmidhi said: Hasan Sahih Hadith. Al-Albani said: Its narrators are trustworthy, the narrators of the two Sheikhs, except Sharik, who - Al-Hafiz said - is truthful but makes many mistakes, and his memory changed after he became a judge in Kufa. So he is weak with this wording. However, its meaning is found in the previous Hadith number 354, which is from Ibn Abbas, so perhaps for that reason Al-Tirmidhi authenticated it.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 368 - (Sahih) When it was said to Tawus: 'O Abu Abdur-Rahman, why don't you abandon this sharecropping (Mukhabarah), for they claim the Messenger of Allah ﷺ forbade it?' He said: 'I help them and give to them.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Ibn Majah.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 369 - (Sahih) The prohibition of renting land and taking a wage or share for it is authentically reported from the Prophet ﷺ. This was narrated from the Prophet ﷺ by two Bedr veterans, Rafi' bin Khadij, Jabir, Abu Sa'id, Abu Hurairah, and Ibn Umar; all of them narrate from the Prophet ﷺ the prohibition of renting land in general. Authentic. See the explanation. Its summary is that these Hadiths - even if some are absolute in prohibition - others, like the Hadith of Rafi', indicate by the sum of their narrations that the prohibition is restricted to cases where there are corrupt conditions leading to dispute. It has come explicitly from the Hadith of Thabit that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ forbade sharecropping and ordered renting, saying there is no harm in it, as preceded under number 364.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 370 - (Sahih) In the Sahih: That the Prophet ﷺ forbade selling fruits in the fields or gardens before their ripeness appears and it is known that they are safe from blight and pests. Authentic. The author mentioned it by meaning. It passed under number 316.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 371 - (Sahih) He ﷺ said: 'Tell me, if Allah withholds the fruit, by what right does one of you take the wealth of his brother?'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 372 - (Sahih) 'The back (riding animal) may be ridden in exchange for its maintenance if it is mortgaged, and the milk of a dairy animal may be drunk in exchange for its maintenance if it is mortgaged; and upon the one who rides and drinks is the maintenance.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 373 - (Sahih) Hanzalah Al-Usaydi - who was one of the scribes of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ - said: 'Abu Bakr met me and said: 'How are you, O Hanzalah?' I said: 'Hanzalah has become a hypocrite.' He said: 'Glory be to Allah! What are you saying?' I said: 'We are with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and he reminds us of the Fire and Paradise until it is as if we are seeing them with our eyes. But when we leave the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, we busy ourselves with wives, children, and properties, and we forget much.' Abu Bakr said: 'By Allah, we encounter the same thing.' Hanzalah said: So I and Abu Bakr went until we entered upon the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. I said: 'Hanzalah has become a hypocrite, O Messenger of Allah.' The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'And what is that?' I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, we are with you and you remind us of the Fire and Paradise until it is as if we are seeing them with our eyes. But when we leave you, we busy ourselves with wives, children, and properties, and we forget much.' The Messenger of Allah said: 'By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, if you were to remain in the state you are in when you are with me and in Dhikr (remembrance), the angels would shake your hands on your beds and in your roads. But O Hanzalah, a time for this and a time for that.' He repeated this phrase - 'a time for this and a time for that' - three times. Authentic. Narrated by Muslim and Al-Tirmidhi, who said it is a Hasan Sahih Hadith. It has a witness with him, as well as Ahmad from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah similarly, adding at the end: 'And if you did not sin, Allah would have brought a new creation so that they would sin and He would forgive them.' Al-Tirmidhi said: Its chain is not that strong. I say: But there is no harm in it for supporting evidence. The mentioned addition is in Muslim. And in another wording: '...with a people who sin and ask Allah for forgiveness, so He forgives them.'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 374 - (Sahih) He ﷺ used to say: 'O Allah, I seek refuge in You from anxiety and sorrow.' Authentic. It is in Abu Dawood from the Hadith of Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri with a weak chain, but Al-Bukhari and others narrated it from the Hadith of Anas bin Malik who said: The Prophet ﷺ used to say: [he mentioned it] and added: 'and laziness, cowardice, miserliness, the burden of debt, and being overpowered by men.' So attributing it to Al-Bukhari was obligatory.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 375 - (Hasan) It is narrated that an old woman came to him saying: 'O Messenger of Allah, pray to Allah for me that He enters me into Paradise.' He said to her: 'O Umm Fulan, Paradise is not entered by an old woman.' The woman became upset and cried, thinking she would not enter Paradise. When he saw that from her, he explained to her his meaning that the old woman will not enter Paradise as an old woman; rather, Allah will create her anew, and she will enter it young and virgin. And he recited to her the saying of Allah the Exalted: {Indeed, We have produced the women of Paradise in a [new] creation. And made them virgins. Devoted [to their husbands] and of equal age.} Hasan. Narrated by Abd bin Humaid, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Bayhaqi, Al-Tabarani, and Al-Baghawi.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 376 - (Hasan) 'Woe to the one who speaks and lies to make people laugh. Woe to him, woe to him.' Hasan. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 377 - (Sahih) Aisha said: 'The Messenger of Allah ﷺ raced me and I beat him. Later, when I had put on weight, he raced me and beat me. He said: 'This is for that (previous time).' Authentic. Extracted in Adab al-Zafaf and Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 378 - (Hasan) The Prophet ﷺ wrestled a man known for his strength named Rukanah, and the Prophet defeated him multiple times. In a narration: The Prophet wrestled him and he was strong. He said: 'A sheep for a sheep.' The Prophet ﷺ threw him. He said: 'Try me again.' He threw him again. He said: 'Try me again.' The Prophet threw him a third time. The man said: 'What shall I tell my family? A sheep eaten by the wolf and a sheep that ran away? What should I say about the third?' The Prophet ﷺ said: 'We would not combine defeating you and fining you. Take your sheep.' Hasan. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Tirmidhi. It was mentioned in the commentary: This must have been before the prohibition of gambling, or the Prophet did not accept this wager and thus did not enforce it.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 379 - (Sahih) From Salamah bin Al-Akwa' who said: The Prophet passed by a group from Aslam practicing archery. The Prophet ﷺ said: 'Shoot, O Banu Ismail, for your father was an archer, and I am with the clan of so-and-so.' One of the two teams held back their hands. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Why are you not shooting?' They said: 'How can we shoot when you are with them?' The Prophet ﷺ said: 'Shoot, for I am with all of you.' Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 380 - (Sahih) 'Verily, strength is archery. Verily, strength is archery. Verily, strength is archery.' Authentic. Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad from the Hadith of Uqbah bin Amir who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah ﷺ while he was on the pulpit saying: '{And prepare against them whatever you are able of power} - Verily, strength is archery.'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 381 - (Sahih) 'Practice archery, for it is among the best of your diversions.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Khatib in Al-Muwaddih.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 382 - (Sahih) That the Prophet ﷺ cursed whoever takes something possessing a soul as a target. Authentic. Narrated by Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad via Sa'id bin Jubayr who said: Ibn Umar passed by some youths of Quraysh who had set up a bird and were shooting at it, giving the owner of the bird every arrow that missed. When they saw Ibn Umar, they dispersed. Ibn Umar said: 'Who did this? Allah has cursed whoever did this. Verily the Messenger of Allah cursed...' The context is from Muslim. As for Al-Bukhari, he narrated it similarly without the last sentence. In a narration by Al-Bukhari: 'The Prophet ﷺ cursed whoever mutilates an animal.' The Hadith has a witness from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Abbas: That the Prophet ﷺ said: 'Do not take anything possessing a soul as a target.' Narrated by Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 383 - (Da'if) The Prophet forbade inciting beasts against one another. Weak. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, and Ibn Adi. Abu Ja'far Al-Razi narrated from Layth from Mujahid from Ibn Umar that he disliked inciting beasts against one another. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad. (Inciting beasts is setting them against each other. Some Arabs used to bring two rams or two bulls to butt heads until they perished or nearly perished, while they watched and laughed).

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 384 - (Sahih) From Abu Hurairah who said: While the Abyssinians were playing with their spears near the Prophet ﷺ, Umar entered and reached for some pebbles to throw at them. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Leave them alone, O Umar.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 385 - (Sahih) Aisha said: 'I saw the Prophet ﷺ screening me with his cloak while I watched the Abyssinians playing in the mosque until I was the one who got bored. So appreciate the young girl who is eager for entertainment.' Agreed upon and extracted in Adab al-Zafaf.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 386 - (Sahih) Aisha (RA) said: 'I used to play with dolls in the house of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ - i.e., toys. I had friends who would play with me. When the Messenger of Allah ﷺ entered, they would hide (out of respect/awe), so he would send them to me to play with me.'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 387 - (Sahih) 'Goodness is tied to the forelocks of horses.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and others via many paths.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 388 - (Da'if) 'Shoot (arrows) and ride.' Weak. Attributing it to Muslim is an error; rather, it was narrated by Ahmad, Al-Tirmidhi, and others.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 389 - (Sahih) 'Everything that is not from the remembrance of Allah is idle play or negligence, except for four traits: a man walking between two targets (for archery), disciplining his horse, playing with his family, and teaching swimming.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Tabarani and Al-Nasa'i.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 390 - (Sahih) From Ibn Umar: The Prophet ﷺ held a race between horses and gave [a prize] to the winner. Authentic. Narrated by Ahmad. Its chain with him is weak, but it has other paths that strengthen it, which I extracted in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 391 - (Hasan) Anas was asked: 'Did you used to bet during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ? Did the Messenger of Allah ﷺ bet?' He said: 'Yes, by Allah, he bet on a horse called Subhah, and it beat the others, so he was delighted by that and impressed.' Hasan. Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Darimi. (Permissible betting is when the prize is offered by someone other than the competitors or by only one of them. But if each of them puts up a stake and the winner takes both stakes, that is the prohibited gambling).

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 392 - (Sahih) 'Horses are of three types: a horse for the Most Merciful, a horse for man, and a horse for Satan. As for the horse of the Most Merciful, it is the one tied in the cause of Allah; its fodder, dung, urine, and whatever Allah wills (of its traces) are good deeds. As for the horse of Satan, it is the one gambled on or bet upon. As for the horse of man, it is the one a man ties seeking its offspring; it is a screen from poverty.' Authentic. Narrated by Ahmad. I have extracted it and mentioned what strengthens it in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 393 - (Sahih) The Prophet ﷺ said: 'Its game is not to be hunted, its trees are not to be cut, and its fodder is not to be harvested.' (Referring to Mecca, for Islam has made it a zone of peace and security for every living being moving in its lands, flying in its skies, or even growing in its soil).

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 394 - (Sahih) 'Whoever says to his companion: 'Come, let me gamble with you,' let him give charity.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 395 - (Hasan) 'Whoever plays with backgammon (Nard) has disobeyed Allah and His Messenger.' Hasan. Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawood, Ibn Majah, and Malik in Al-Muwatta. Its chain is interrupted, but it has another path from Abu Musa by which the Hadith is strengthened. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 396 - (Sahih) 'Whoever plays with Nardashir (backgammon), it is as if he dipped his hand in the flesh and blood of a swine.' Authentic. Narrated by Muslim, Ahmad, and Abu Dawood. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 397 - (Sahih) From Aisha (RA), that she led a woman to her husband from the Ansar. The Prophet ﷺ said: 'O Aisha, was there no entertainment with them? For the Ansar love entertainment.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari. It is in Adab al-Zafaf.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 398 - (Hasan) Ibn Abbas said: Aisha married off a relative of hers from the Ansar. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ came and said: 'Have you gifted the girl?' They said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Did you send someone with her to sing?' She said: 'No.' The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Verily the Ansar are a people who love poetry (Ghazal), so if only you had sent with her someone to say: We have come to you, we have come to you, so greet us and we greet you.' Hasan. Narrated by Ibn Majah. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 399 - (Sahih) From Aisha: Abu Bakr entered upon her while she had two girls with her during the days of Mina (Eid al-Adha) singing and beating (drums). The Prophet ﷺ was covered with his garment. Abu Bakr scolded them, so the Prophet ﷺ uncovered his face and said: 'Leave them alone, O Abu Bakr, for these are days of Eid.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Al-Nasa'i, and Ahmad. See the long explanation regarding the refutation of the absolute permissibility of singing.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 400 - (Sahih) His ﷺ saying to Aisha initially: 'Do you wish to watch?' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim from the Hadith of Aisha in a narration regarding the Abyssinians playing with their spears, which preceded under number 186.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 401 - (Sahih) 'Actions are but by intentions, and every person shall have what he intended.' Agreed upon. It is extracted in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 402 - (Sahih) 'People from my Ummah will certainly drink wine (intoxicants), calling it by other than its name. Musical instruments and singing girls will be played over their heads. Allah will cause the earth to swallow them up and make them into monkeys and pigs.' Authentic. Narrated by Ibn Majah, Abu Dawood, Ibn Hibban, Ahmad, and others.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 403 - (Hasan) 'For one of you to be stabbed in the head with an iron needle is better for him than to touch a woman who is not lawful for him.' Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi and Al-Tabarani. It is in Silsilat al-Sahihah 226.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 404 - (Sahih) 'Do not envy one another, do not turn your backs on one another, do not hate one another, and be servants of Allah, brothers.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Malik; Abu Dawood narrated from him.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 405 - (Da'if) 'It is not lawful for a Muslim to forsake his brother for more than three days. If three days pass, let him meet him and greet him with peace. If he returns the greeting, they share in the reward; but if he does not return it, he bears the sin, and the Muslim has absolved himself of the forsaking.' Weak. Narrated by Abu Dawood, and similarly by Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad. Sufficient in this chapter is the Hadith of Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'It is not lawful for a Muslim to forsake his brother for more than three nights; they meet and this one turns away and that one turns away, and the best of them is the one who initiates the greeting.' Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 406 - (Sahih) 'The womb (kinship) is suspended from the Throne saying: Whoever connects me, Allah connects him; and whoever cuts me, Allah cuts him.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad and Muslim. The wording is Muslim's. The wording of Al-Bukhari is: 'The womb is a branch (Shujnah) - whoever connects it, I connect him; and whoever cuts it, I cut him.' This is his wording in the Sahih. His wording in the other book is: 'The womb is a branch from Allah - whoever connects it, Allah connects him; and whoever cuts it, Allah cuts him.' Ahmad narrated it with the wording: 'Verily the womb is suspended from the Throne, and the maintainer is not the one who reciprocates, but the maintainer is the one who, when his ties are cut, connects them.' It has another path in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad by Al-Bukhari saying: 'The womb is a branch from the Most Merciful; whoever connects it, He connects him, and whoever cuts it, He cuts him. It has a tongue that is eloquent and sharp on the Day of Resurrection.'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 407 - (Sahih) 'No severer [of ties] enters Paradise.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (and in the other book), Muslim, and Al-Tirmidhi. Muslim and Al-Tirmidhi added: Sufyan said: Meaning a severer of kinship ties.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 408 - (Sahih) 'The maintainer [of ties] is not the one who reciprocates, but the maintainer is the one who, when his ties are cut, connects them.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad, as well as Al-Tirmidhi and Ahmad. Ahmad added at the beginning in a narration: 'Verily the womb is suspended from the Throne.' Its chain is authentic.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 409 - (Sahih) The Prophet ﷺ boycotted his three companions who stayed behind in the Battle of Tabuk for fifty days, until the earth, despite its vastness, became constricted for them, and their souls became constricted for them. No one would sit with them, speak to them, or greet them until Allah revealed in His Book His acceptance of their repentance. Authentic. This is the meaning of a part of the Hadith of Ka'b bin Malik regarding the story of his staying behind and his repentance. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Abu Dawood (abbreviated), Al-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad from him.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 410 - (Sahih) From Jabir bin Abdullah who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ boycotted his wives for a month. He was in the upper room and they were in the lower room. The Prophet ﷺ came down to them after twenty-nine nights. A man said: 'O Messenger of Allah, you stayed for twenty-nine nights.' The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'The month is like this and like this' (showing the fingers of his hand twice, and on the third time, he tucked in his thumb). Narrated by Ahmad with an authentic chain on the condition of Muslim, and he narrated it in his Sahih with its meaning abbreviated. From Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ boycotted his wives for a month. When twenty-nine days passed, Gabriel came to him and said: 'Your oath has been fulfilled, and the month is complete.' Its chain is authentic on the condition of Muslim, and it is in Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 411 - (Sahih) Abdullah bin Umar boycotted a son of his until he died because he did not submit to a Hadith his father mentioned from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ in which he forbade men from preventing women from going to the mosques. Authentic. Narrated by Ahmad from Mujahid from Abdullah bin Umar that the Prophet ﷺ said: 'Let no man prevent his family from coming to the mosques.' A son of Abdullah bin Umar said: 'We prevent them.' Abdullah said: 'I tell you from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and you say this?' He said: So Abdullah did not speak to him until he died. Its chain is authentic. It is in Muslim without the phrase 'So he did not speak to him'.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 412 - (Sahih) 'The gates of Paradise are opened on Monday and Thursday, and Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, forgives every servant who does not associate anything with Allah, except a man who has a grudge between him and his brother. He says: Wait for these two until they reconcile, wait for these two until they reconcile, wait for these two until they reconcile.' Authentic. Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Malik, and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 413 - (Da'if) 'Whoever has an apology offered to him and does not accept it will not come to me at the Cistern (Hawd).' Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat, and it is weak.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 414 - (Sahih) 'Shall I not guide you to something better than the rank of prayer, fasting, and charity?' They said: 'Yes, O Messenger of Allah.' He said: 'Reconciling between people, for the corruption of relations is the shaver (destroyer). I do not say it shaves hair, but it shaves religion.' Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi, Abu Dawood, Ibn Hibban, and Ahmad from the Hadith of Abu Darda. Its chain is authentic on the condition of the two Sheikhs, but the statement 'I do not say it shaves hair...' is not in the Hadith; rather, Al-Tirmidhi appended it after the Hadith and its authentication.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 415 - (Sahih) 'Verily Allah does not look at your forms nor your wealth, but He looks at your hearts and your deeds.' Authentic. Narrated by Muslim, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad. In a narration by Muslim: '...at your bodies nor at your forms...'

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 416 - (Hasan) About Ibn Mas'ud: He was harvesting Siwak from an Arak tree, and he had thin legs. The wind started to blow him about, so the people laughed at him. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'What are you laughing at?' They said: 'At the thinness of his legs.' He said: 'By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, they are heavier in the Scale than Mount Uhud.' Narrated by Al-Tayalisi from Hammad from Asim from Zirr bin Hubaysh from Ibn Mas'ud, and its chain is Hasan.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 417 - (Sahih) 'Beware of suspicion, for suspicion is the most false of speech.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, Malik, Al-Tirmidhi, and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 418 - (Da'if) 'If you suspect, do not verify.' Narrated by Al-Tabarani, and its chain is weak.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 419 - (Da'if) 'Whoever conceals a defect/nakedness, it is as if he brought a buried alive girl back to life from her grave.' Weak. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Ibn Hibban (the wording is his), and Al-Hakim.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 420 - (Hasan) From Ibn Umar who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ ascended the pulpit and called out with a loud voice saying: 'O community of those who have believed with their tongues but faith has not entered their hearts! Do not harm the Muslims, and do not pursue their faults. For whoever pursues the faults of his Muslim brother, Allah pursues his faults; and whoever Allah pursues his faults, He exposes him even if he is in the interior of his house.' Hasan. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and Ibn Hibban.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 421 - (Sahih) 'Whoever peeks into the house of a people without their permission, it becomes lawful for them to gouge out his eye.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim. The wording of Al-Bukhari is: 'If a man peeks at you without permission and you throw a pebble at him and gouge out his eye, there is no sin upon you.' It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 422 - (Sahih) 'Whoever listens to the conversation of a people when they dislike it, molten lead will be poured into his ears on the Day of Resurrection.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, Ahmad, and Al-Tabarani. The correct wording is 'his ear' in the singular.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 423 - (Da'if) 'Any man who lifts a curtain and inserts his gaze before he is given permission has committed an offense unlawful for him to commit.' Weak. Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Tirmidhi.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 424 - (Sahih) Mu'awiyah narrated from the Messenger ﷺ: 'If you pursue the faults of people, you corrupt them, or almost corrupt them.' Authentic. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ibn Hibban.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 425 - (Sahih) 'If the ruler seeks suspicion among the people, he corrupts them.' Authentic. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Tahawi, Al-Hakim, Ahmad, and Ibn Asakir in Tarikh Dimashq.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 426 - (Sahih) 'Do you know what backbiting is?' They said: 'Allah and His Messenger know best.' He said: 'Mentioning your brother with what he dislikes.' It was said: 'What if what I say is present in my brother?' He said: 'If what you say is in him, you have backbitten him; and if what you say is not in him, you have slandered him.' Authentic. Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Darimi, and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 427 - (Sahih) From Aisha: I said to the Prophet ﷺ: 'It is enough for you that Safiyyah (the Prophet's wife) is such and such' - meaning she is short. The Prophet ﷺ said: 'You have said a word that, if mixed with the water of the sea, would spoil it.' Authentic. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Ahmad, and Al-Tahawi.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 428 - (Sahih) Ibn Mas'ud said: We were with the Prophet ﷺ. A man stood up (i.e., left the gathering), and another man spoke ill of him after he left. The Prophet ﷺ said to this man: 'Pick your teeth.' He said: 'Why should I pick my teeth when I have not eaten meat?' He said: 'You have eaten the flesh of your brother.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 429 - (Hasan) From Jabir: We were with the Prophet ﷺ and a foul wind blew. The Messenger ﷺ said: 'Do you know what this wind is? This is the smell of those who backbite the believers.' Hasan. Narrated by Ahmad, Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad, and Ibn Hibban. The Hadith has another path in Al-Bukhari via Sulayman from Abu Sufyan from Jabir who said: 'A foul wind stirred during the time of the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Some hypocrites backbit some Muslims, so this wind was sent for that reason.'' This chain is good.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 430 - (Sahih) Fatimah bint Qais informed the Prophet ﷺ about two men who proposed to her. He said about one: 'He is a pauper with no wealth.' And about the other: 'He does not put down his stick from his shoulder' - meaning he beats women often. Authentic. Narrated by Muslim and others. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 431 - (Sahih) 'Whoever defends the honor of his brother against backbiting, it is a right upon Allah to free him from the Fire.' Authentic. Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Al-Sheikh in Al-Fawa'id, Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in Al-Samt, Al-Khara'iti in Makarim Al-Akhlaq, Sakhtam Al-Faqih in Al-Fawa'id Al-Muntaqah, Ibn Adi in Al-Kamil, and Abu Nu'aym in Al-Hilyah. See the rest of the explanation in the book.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 432 - (Hasan) 'Whoever repels [harm] from the honor of his brother in this world, Allah will repel the Fire from his face on the Day of Resurrection.' Hasan. See the explanation.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 433 - (Sahih) 'A tale-carrier (Qattat) will not enter Paradise.' Authentic. Narrated by Al-Bukhari in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad, Muslim, Abu Dawood, Al-Tirmidhi, Ahmad, and Ibn Abi Al-Dunya in Al-Samt from the Hadith of Hudhayfah in Marfu' form. Al-Tirmidhi said: Hasan Sahih Hadith. (The Qattat is the Namam [malicious gossip]. It is said: The Namm is one who is with a group speaking and gossips about them, while the Qattat is one who eavesdrops on them without their knowledge and then gossips).

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 434 - (Hasan) 'The worst of Allah's servants are those who walk about with gossip (Namimah), dividing those who love each other, seeking defects for the innocent.' Narrated by Ahmad in the Musnad via Abu Al-Hasan from Shahr bin Hawshab, and its chain is weak. It has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Verily the most beloved of you to Allah are those with the best character, who are humble and easy-going, who unite and are united. And verily the most hated of you to Allah are those who walk about with gossip, dividing brothers, seeking stumbling blocks for the innocent.' Narrated by Ibn Abi Al-Dunya via Salih Al-Murri, who is weak, so perhaps the Hadith becomes Hasan with this witness.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 435 - (Hasan) Abdullah bin Umar (RA) looked at the Kaaba one day and said: 'How great are you, and how great is your sanctity! But the believer has greater sanctity than you.' Hasan. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and Ibn Hibban.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 436 - (Sahih) In the Farewell Pilgrimage, the Prophet ﷺ addressed the gathering of Muslims saying: 'Verily your wealth, your honor, and your blood are sacred to you, like the sanctity of this day of yours, in this month of yours, in this land of yours.' Authentic.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 437 - (Da'if) 'Whoever mentions something about a person that is not true to fault him with it, Allah will imprison him in the Fire of Hell until he provides a way out for what he said.' Weak. See the explanation.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 438 - (Da'if/Weak) From Aisha that the Prophet ﷺ said to his companions: "Do you know what is the worst Riba (usury) in the sight of Allah?" They said: "Allah and His Messenger know best." He said: "The worst Riba in the sight of Allah is violating the honor of a Muslim." Then the Messenger of Allah ﷺ recited: {And those who harm believing men and believing women for [something] other than what they have earned have certainly born upon themselves a slander and manifest sin.} [Al-Ahzab: 58]. Weak. Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim, Ibn Mardawayh, and Al-Bayhaqi.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 439 - (Sahih/Authentic) "The vanishing of the world is lesser in the sight of Allah than the killing of a Muslim man." Sahih. Narrated by An-Nasa'i and At-Tirmidhi.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 440 - (Sahih) "A believer continues to be within the scope (of mercy) of his religion as long as he does not spill unlawful blood." Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Ahmad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 441 - (Sahih) "Every sin might be forgiven by Allah except for a man who dies as a polytheist or a man who kills a believer intentionally." Sahih. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Ibn Hibban, and Al-Hakim.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 442 - (Agreed upon) "Abusing a Muslim is Fusuq (evil-doing/transgression) and killing him is Kufr (disbelief)."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 443 - (Agreed upon) "Do not revert to being disbelievers after me, striking the necks of one another." Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Ahmad from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, attributed to the Prophet ﷺ.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 444 - (Agreed upon) "When two Muslims raise weapons against each other, they are on the brink of Hellfire. If one of them kills the other, they both enter it." It was said: "O Messenger of Allah, this is the killer, but what about the killed?" He said: "He intended to kill his companion."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 445 - (Sahih) "None of you should point a weapon at his brother, for he does not know, perhaps Satan might cause his hand to slip, resulting in him falling into a pit of Fire." Sahih. Narrated by Muslim, An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, and Ahmad; the wording is Muslim's. In another narration by him: "If two Muslims face each other with their swords, then the killer and the killed are in the Fire." I said, or it was said: "O Messenger of Allah, this is the killer..." etc. It was also narrated by Al-Bukhari, Abu Dawood, and Ahmad. In a narration by Al-Bukhari: "He was eager to kill his companion." The Hadith has supporting evidence from the Hadith of Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari attributed to the Prophet ﷺ with a similar meaning, narrated by An-Nasa'i, Ibn Majah, Ibn Khuzaimah, and Ahmad, and its narrators are trustworthy.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 446 - (Sahih) "Whoever points a piece of iron at his brother, the angels curse him until he stops, even if it is his brother from his father and mother." Sahih. Narrated by Muslim. The Hadith has supporting evidence from the Hadith of Aisha (RA) attributed to the Prophet ﷺ with the wording: "Whoever points a piece of iron at any Muslim intending to kill him, his blood becomes lawful." Narrated by Ahmad via Alqamah from his mother in a story he mentioned, so Aisha narrated it. This chain has trustworthy narrators except Umm Alqamah, who is unknown.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 447 - (Sahih) "It is not lawful for a Muslim to frighten another Muslim." Sahih. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Ahmad via Al-A'mash from Abdullah bin Yasar from Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Layla who said: The Companions of Muhammad ﷺ told us that they were traveling with the Prophet ﷺ. A man among them fell asleep, so another man went to a rope he had and took it, which frightened him. So the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: (the mentioned text). This chain is authentic. His saying "Habl" (rope) with a 'Ha' is how it appeared in At-Targhib and Sunan Abu Dawood, but in Al-Musnad it appeared as "Nabl" (arrows) with a 'Nun', which is the correct one.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 448 - (Da'if/Weak) "Let none of you stand in a place where a man is being killed unjustly, for the curse descends upon whoever is present and does not defend him." Weak. Narrated by At-Tabarani in Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir, Al-Uqayli in Ad-Du'afa, and Abu Nu'aym in Al-Hilyah. At-Tabarani also narrated with a very weak chain from Ibn Abbas who said: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: "Your Lord said: By My Might and Majesty, I will surely take vengeance on the oppressor sooner or later, and I will surely take vengeance on whoever saw an oppressed person and was able to help him but did not."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 449 - (Sahih) "Whoever kills a Mu'ahid (a non-Muslim under covenant/protection) shall not smell the fragrance of Paradise, though its fragrance can be found from a distance of forty years." Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, An-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah from the Hadith of Abdullah bin Amr from the Prophet ﷺ. The wording of An-Nasa'i is: "Whoever kills a victim from the People of the Dhimmah..." Ahmad narrated it likewise, and Al-Hakim authenticated it based on the criteria of the Two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim), and Ad-Dhahabi agreed.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 450 - (Sahih) "Whoever kills a man from the People of the Dhimmah will not find the fragrance of Paradise." Sahih. Narrated by An-Nasa'i. It has supporting evidence from the Hadith of Abu Huraira attributed to the Prophet ﷺ with the wording: "Verily, whoever kills a Mu'ahid who has the covenant of Allah and the covenant of His Messenger has violated the covenant of Allah and shall not smell the fragrance of Paradise, though its fragrance can be found from a distance of seventy autumns (years)." Narrated by Al-Hakim via Ma'di bin Sulayman, who is weak.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 451 - (Sahih) "The blood of a Muslim man is not lawful except in one of three cases: a life for a life, the married adulterer, and the one who abandons his religion and separates from the community." Agreed upon. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 452 - (Sahih) "Among those before you was a man who had a wound. He became impatient and took a knife and cut his hand with it. The blood did not stop flowing until he died. Allah said: 'My servant hastened to bring about his end by himself; I have forbidden Paradise for him.'" Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari (this is his wording) and Muslim similarly.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 453 - (Sahih) "Whoever throws himself down from a mountain and kills himself will be in the Fire of Hell, throwing himself down therein, abiding eternally and forever. Whoever drinks poison and kills himself will carry his poison in his hand, drinking it in the Fire of Hell, abiding eternally and forever. Whoever kills himself with a piece of iron will carry his piece of iron in his hand, stabbing himself with it in the Fire of Hell, abiding eternally and forever." Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, An-Nasa'i, At-Tirmidhi, Ad-Darimi, and Ahmad. Abu Dawood narrated from him only the case of the poison. They narrated it from the Hadith of Abu Huraira.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 454 - (Sahih) "How excellent is righteous wealth for a righteous man." Sahih. Narrated by Ahmad; Abdur-Rahman told us, Musa bin Ali told us from his father who said: I heard Amr bin Al-Aas say: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ sent for me and said: "Put on your clothes and weapons then come to me." So I came to him while he was performing ablution. He looked up at me and then looked down and said: "I want to send you with an army so that Allah may keep you safe and grant you war booty, and I desire for you a righteous portion of wealth." I said: "O Messenger of Allah, I did not accept Islam for the sake of wealth, but I accepted Islam out of desire for Islam and to be with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ." So he said: "O Amr, how excellent..." (the text). Then Ahmad, Abu Ya'la, Al-Hakim, Al-Baghawi, Al-Quda'i, and Ibn Asakir narrated it via other routes from Musa bin Ali with it.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 455 - (Sahih) "The thief does not steal at the time he steals while he is a believer." Agreed upon. Sahih. They (Bukhari and Muslim) narrated it from the Hadith of Abu Huraira.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 456 - (Sahih) "It is not lawful for a Muslim to take a stick (from another) without his willing consent." Sahih. Narrated by Ibn Hibban and Ahmad. In a narration, he added: "He said that because of the severity of what Allah has made inviolable regarding a Muslim's property to another Muslim." In a narration by Ahmad: "It is not lawful for a man to take his brother's property without right; this is because of what Allah has made inviolable regarding the property of a Muslim to another Muslim."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 457 - (Hasan) "The curse of Allah is upon the briber and the bribed in judgment." Hasan. Narrated by Ahmad, At-Tirmidhi, Ibn Hibban, and likewise Al-Hakim.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 458 - (Da'if/Weak) From Thawban who said: "The Messenger of Allah ﷺ cursed the briber, the bribed, and the mediator (Rai'sh)." Weak. Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Hakim. It is in "Al-Ahadith Ad-Da'ifah" (1235).

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 459 - (Sahih) The Messenger of Allah ﷺ sent Abdullah bin Rawaha to the Jews to estimate what was due from them regarding the tax on their date palms. They offered him some wealth to give to him. He said to them: "As for the bribe you have offered, it is Suht (illicit gain/unlawful), and we do not eat it." Narrated by Malik in Al-Muwatta from Ibn Shihab from Sulayman bin Yasar that the Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to send Abdullah bin Rawaha to Khaybar to estimate the produce between him and the Jews of Khaybar. He said: They collected jewelry from their women's jewelry and said to him: "This is for you; go easy on us and overlook the division." Abdullah bin Rawaha said: "O assembly of Jews! By Allah, you are among the most hated of Allah's creation to me, but that will not induce me to deal unjustly with you. As for what you have offered..." etc. He added: They said: "By this (justice), the heavens and the earth are established." This chain is Mursal Sahih. In a fuller narration: Allah granted Khaybar as Fai' to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, so the Messenger of Allah ﷺ approved them to stay as they were and made it (the produce) shared between him and them. He sent Abdullah bin Rawaha who estimated it for them, then said to them: "O assembly of Jews, you are the most hated of creation to me; you killed the Prophets of Allah and lied against Allah. However, my hatred for you will not induce me to deal unjustly with you. I have estimated twenty thousand Wasq of dates. If you wish, it is yours (to keep and pay the half), and if you refuse, it is mine." They said: "By this, the heavens and the earth are established. We have accepted, so leave us." Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Dawood up to his saying "who estimated it for them", and their chains are authentic.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 460 - (Sahih) "Whomever we employ for a task and provide him with sustenance (a salary), whatever he takes after that is Ghulul (stealing from public funds/betrayal)." Sahih. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 461 - (Sahih) "The Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to accept gifts." Sahih. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 462 - (Sahih) The Messenger ﷺ sent a governor to collect the charity (Sadaqah) of Al-Azd - a tribe. When he came to the Messenger, he withheld some of what he had and said: "This is for you and this is a gift for me." The Prophet became angry and said: "Why didn't you sit in your father's house and your mother's house until your gift came to you, if you were truthful?" Then he said: "What is the matter with me that I employ a man among you and he says: 'This is for you and this is a gift for me'? Why didn't he sit in his mother's house to be given a gift? By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, none of you takes anything without right except that he will come to Allah carrying it" meaning on the Day of Resurrection. "Let not one of you come on the Day of Resurrection with a camel grumbling, or a cow mooing, or a sheep bleating." Then he raised his hands until the whiteness of his armpits was seen, then said: "O Allah, have I conveyed?" Sahih. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 463 - (Sahih) From Umar (RA) who said: Two men entered upon the Prophet ﷺ asking him for something. He helped them with two dinars. They went out praising him well. I entered upon him and said: "O Messenger of Allah, I saw so-and-so and so-and-so go out from you praising well." He said: "But so-and-so does not say that, although I gave him between ten to a hundred, yet he does not say that. Verily, one of you leaves with his charity from me carrying it under his arm, while it is but fire for him." Umar said: "O Messenger of Allah, how do you give it to him while knowing it is fire for him?" He said: "What can I do? They refuse but to ask me, and Allah the Mighty and Majestic refuses stinginess for me." Sahih. Cited by Al-Haythami in Al-Majma'.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 464 - (Sahih) "The Messenger ﷺ forbade the wasting of wealth."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 465 - (Sahih) "Start with yourself and give charity to it. If anything remains, then for your family. If anything remains from your family, then for your relatives. If anything remains from your relatives, then like this and like this" saying: in front of you, on your right, and on your left. Sahih. Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawood, An-Nasa'i, and others. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 466 - (Sahih) "The best charity - or the most excellent charity - is that which leaves behind richness. The upper hand is better than the lower hand. And begin with those you support." Sahih. Narrated by Ahmad; it is in Muslim and others, and Al-Bukhari and others narrated it via another route. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 467 - (Da'if/Weak) From Jabir bin Abdullah who said: While we were with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, a man came to him with a piece of gold like an egg and said: "O Messenger of Allah, take this as charity, for by Allah I possess nothing else." He turned away from him angrily. Then he took it from him and threw it at him such that if it had hit him, it would have hurt him. Then he said: "One of you comes to me with his wealth possessing nothing else, then he sits begging from people. Charity is only out of surplus wealth. Take it, we have no need for it." Weak. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Hakim. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 468 - (Sahih) "He used to store provisions for his family for a year." Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, and likewise Muslim from the Hadith of Umar bin Al-Khattab (RA).

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 469 - (Da'if/Weak) "Whoever harms a Dhimmi (non-Muslim citizen) has harmed me, and whoever harms me has harmed Allah." At-Tabarani in Al-Awsat. It has no basis with this wording neither in At-Tabarani nor elsewhere. The origin of the Hadith is "Whoever harms a Muslim..." It was reported from Anas bin Malik who said: While the Messenger of Allah ﷺ was delivering a sermon, a man came stepping over people's necks until he sat near the Prophet ﷺ. When the Messenger of Allah ﷺ finished his prayer, he said: "What prevented you, O so-and-so, from joining the congregation?" He said: "O Messenger of Allah, I strove to place myself in the spot you see." He said: "I saw you stepping over people's necks, harming them. Whoever harms a Muslim has..." the Hadith. Only Al-Qasim Al-Ajli Al-Basri narrated it from Anas, and only Musa bin Khalaf narrated it from him. He [Musa] is truthful but has delusions. Regarding Al-Qasim bin Mutayyib, he used to make many mistakes, so he deserved to be abandoned. Ad-Dhahabi included him in "Ad-Du'afa" (The Weak Narrators).

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 470 - (Munkar/Denounced) "Whoever harms a Dhimmi, I am his adversary, and whoever I am his adversary, I will dispute with him on the Day of Resurrection." Munkar. Narrated by Al-Khatib in Tarikh Baghdad.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 472 - (Sahih) "Hate your enemy gently (moderately), for perhaps he may become your beloved one day." Narrated by At-Tirmidhi and Al-Bayhaqi in Shu'ab Al-Iman from Abu Huraira. As-Suyuti marked it as Hasan. Its beginning is: "Love your beloved gently (moderately), for perhaps he may become your hated one day." Al-Bukhari narrated it in Al-Adab Al-Mufrad from Ali as a Mawquf narration. See the long explanation in the book; the summary is that the Hadith via the route of Ibn Sirin is authentically attributed to the Prophet (Marfu') without doubt, and Allah knows best.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 471 - (Hasan) "Whoever wrongs a Mu'ahid, detracts from his rights, burdens him beyond his capacity, or takes something from him without his willing consent, I am his disputant on the Day of Resurrection." Hasan. Narrated by Abu Dawood and Al-Bayhaqi. He added in it: "The Messenger of Allah ﷺ pointed with his finger to his chest: 'Behold, whoever kills a Mu'ahid who has the covenant of Allah and the covenant of His Messenger, Allah has forbidden the fragrance of Paradise upon him, though its fragrance can be found from a distance of seventy autumns.'" Its chain is Jayyid (good).

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 473 - (Sahih) "It is established that kings gave gifts to the Prophet ﷺ and he accepted from them." Sahih. Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tirmidhi.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 474 - (Da'if/Weak) From Umm Salamah, the wife of the Prophet ﷺ, that he said to her: "I have sent a gift to Negus (An-Najashi) consisting of a robe and ounces of silk." Weak. Narrated by Ahmad and At-Tabarani. It is in Al-Irwa.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 475 - (Sahih) A funeral procession passed by the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, so he stood up for it. It was said to him: "O Messenger of Allah, it is the funeral of a Jew." He said: "Is it not a soul?" Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, and likewise Muslim and An-Nasa'i. (Benefit: This Hadith is abrogated by authentic Hadiths explicit in abrogation, some of which I mentioned in my book 'Ahkam Al-Jana'iz wa Bida'uha').

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 476 - (Sahih) "That a man found a dog panting from thirst, so he went down a well and filled his shoe with water from it and watered the dog until it was quenched." The Messenger... The Messenger ﷺ said: "So Allah thanked him." The Companions said: "Is there a reward for us in (serving) animals, O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "In every moist liver (living creature) there is a reward." Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and others from the Hadith of Abu Huraira attributed to the Prophet ﷺ with a fuller text. See Silsilat As-Sahihah 29.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 477 - (Sahih) "A woman entered the Fire because of a cat she imprisoned; she neither fed it nor let it eat from the vermin of the earth." Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim. It is in Silsilat As-Sahihah 28.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 478 - (Sahih) The Prophet ﷺ saw a donkey branded on the face (cauterized on its face), so he disapproved of that and said: "By Allah, I will not brand except on the furthest part from the face." Sahih. Narrated by Muslim from Ibn Abbas who said: (mentioned it) and added: "So he ordered regarding a donkey of his, and it was branded on its buttocks (Ja'aratain). He was the first to brand the buttocks." The Ja'aratan are the two protruding edges of the hip near the rear.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 479 - (Sahih) That a donkey which had been branded on its face passed by him ﷺ, so he said: "Has it not reached you that I cursed the one who brands an animal on its face or strikes it on its face?" Sahih. Narrated by Abu Dawood.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 480 - (Sahih) Hadith: "That the Prophet ﷺ cursed the one who uses something possessing a soul as a target (for shooting practice)."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 481 - (Da'if/Weak) Abdullah bin Abbas said: "The Prophet ﷺ forbade inciting animals against each other."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 482 - (Incorrect/Not Authentic) Ibn Abbas narrated that the Prophet ﷺ forbade the castration of animals strictly. This is not correct as such. However, the Hadith has supporting evidence from the Hadith of Ibn Umar who said: "The Messenger of Allah ﷺ forbade the castration of horses and animals." Ibn Umar said: "In them is the growth of creation." Narrated by Ahmad and Ibn Adi in Al-Kamil. In its chain is weakness, but the Hadith has other routes which, when combined, raise it to the rank of Hasan at the very least.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 483 - (Da'if/Weak) Hadith of Safiyyah bint Shaybah who said: While we were with Aisha, she said: They mentioned the women of Quraysh and their virtue. She said: "Indeed, the women of Quraysh have virtue, but by Allah, I have not seen anyone better than the women of the Ansar, nor more strong in verifying the Book of Allah, nor having more faith in the Revelation. When Surah An-Nur was revealed {and to draw their veils over their bosoms}, their men returned to them reciting what Allah had revealed regarding them. A man would recite to his wife, daughter, sister, and every female relative. Not a woman among them but got up to her embroidered (decorated with images) wrapper and wrapped her head with it, out of verification and faith in what Allah revealed from His Book. They became behind the Messenger of Allah ﷺ wrapped up as if there were crows on their heads." Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim. Weak in this context and completeness. Some of it has been authenticated by Al-Bukhari as mentioned before. Some parts have supporting evidence from the Hadith of Umm Salamah who said: "When {they should bring down over themselves some of their outer garments} was revealed, the women of the Ansar went out as if there were crows on their heads because of the outer garments." Narrated by Abu Dawood with an authentic chain.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 484 - (Da'if/Weak) "If Allah intends good for a person, He appoints for him a preacher from within himself."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 34 - (Sahih) From Ibn Abbas who said: The people of Jahiliyyah used to eat some things and leave some things out of considerating them filthy. So Allah sent His Prophet and revealed His Book, making lawful His Halal and unlawful His Haram. Whatever He made lawful is Halal, whatever He made unlawful is Haram, and whatever He remained silent about is pardoned (Afw). And he recited: {Say, "I do not find within that which was revealed to me [anything] forbidden to one who would eat it..."} the Verse. Sahih. Narrated by Abu Dawood.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 40 - (Da'if/Weak) Umar saw a man dragging a sheep by its leg to slaughter it. He said to him: "Woe to you! Lead it to death in a beautiful manner." Weak. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 163 - (Mawdu'/Fabricated) Ibn Abbas narrated that David was a smith (maker of chainmail and armor), Adam was a farmer, Noah was a carpenter, Idris was a tailor, and Moses was a shepherd. Fabricated. Narrated by Al-Hakim.

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 225 - (Sahih) From Ibn Abbas: A questioner asked him about Mut'ah (temporary marriage) with women, and he permitted it. A client of his said to him: "That is only in severe conditions and scarcity of women" or similar. Ibn Abbas said: "Yes." Sahih. Narrated by Al-Bukhari. In Sahih Muslim and Al-Bayhaqi from Ibn Abi Amrah Al-Ansari that he said to Ibn Abbas while he was giving a fatwa permitting Mut'ah: "Slow down! It was a concession in the beginning of Islam for one compelled to it, like carrion, blood, and pork, then Allah perfected the religion and forbade it."

book_title: Ghayat al-Maram fi Takhrij Ahadith al-Halal wal-Haram
text: 229 - (Da'if/Weak) When it became clear to Ibn Abbas (RA) that people were indulging excessively in it - meaning Mut'ah - and did not limit themselves to cases of necessity, he withheld his fatwa and retracted it. Weak. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi.
